newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli shares close lower on profit taking.
newsitem.headline: Israeli shares close lower on profit taking.

text.p: Israeli shares closed lower on Tuesday in what traders described as a technical correction following a rise of 12 percent since the beginning of the year, traders said.
The benchmark Mishtanim index of the top 100 shares fell 0.48 percent, or 1.12 points, to 233.80 on all-share turnover of 172 million shekels against 216 million shekels on Monday.
The Maof 25 blue chip index closed 0.54 percent lower at 241.61.
"Today's decline is part of a technical correction, which is nothing unusual. Investors started taking profits towards the end of Monday's trading day and continued today," said one trader.
"The correction is a healthy step needed before the market can resume its rise. The most active players continue to be mutual funds which specialise in stocks," he said.
Traders noted that the market was indifferent to the release of December's CPI due on Wednesday, saying that investors expect a moderate rise of 0.5-0.7 percent.
"We were all expecting this correction. The decline was very moderate and many investors used the opportunity to buy," said Ron Weisberg at I.B.I Investment House.

Koor Industries, the most active share, rose 0.5 percent to 31,547 agorot on high volume of 16.8 million shekels. A Koor source said on Tuesday that the company intends to sell its 24.5 percent stake in Israel Edible Products, a food maker, to the U.S. company CPC International.
Industrial Buildings, the second active share, surged 4.0 percent to 442 on turnover of 7.0 million shekels. Traders said there was no evident reason for the rise.
Leumi Insurance Holdings rose 1.5 percent to 230 on volume of 6.3 million shekels.
